sentences.sentence: Canadians are wary of China - very wary.
According to our recent poll, 75 per cent of respondents described the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang province as a "genocide."
Similarly, three-quarters of Canadians believe that China poses "a direct threat to Canada's national security and sovereignty."

Even more troubling, 73 per cent of Canadians believe that China is "responsible" for the COVID-19 pandemic.Unusually for a country as large and diverse as Canada, this strong sense of mistrust is widespread across all regions and sociodemographic groups, with very little difference from one community to another.Clearly, in Canada as in other Western countries, the policies of Chinese President Xi Jinping's regime have profoundly undermined the goodwill that China had built up over the last several decades, as it opened its economy to the world.

Last year, few people celebrated the 50th anniversary of the re-establishment of diplomatic relations between Canada and China.Today, Canada-China relations are in what is by far the most turbulent period since 1970.
The detention of the "two Michaels" is obviously the most serious irritant.
But there is more.

Human rights abuses shock Canadians, so much so that when they were asked whether what is happening in Xinjiang is a genocide and were reminded of the dictionary definition - "the deliberate killing of a large group of people, especially those of a particular nation or ethnic group" - the vast majority said "yes.

"When respondents were given a choice between two statements about China's role in the pandemic - "China serves as a model for the way it managed to stop COVID-19 from spreading beyond the city of Wuhan" and "China is responsible for the global COVID-19 pandemic, because of its mismanagement of the situation in the early stages of the pandemic" - the second statement clearly won out.In this context, formulating a Canadian policy towards China is not easy.

According to our survey, the vast majority (71 per cent) want Ottawa to denounce Beijing's human rights violations loudly and clearly, in concert with our allies.Yet, as former Foreign Affairs Minister FranÃ§ois-Philippe Champagne said, "While it is easy to be tough, let's continue to be smart."

That is what the current situation demands: firmness on principles, certainly, but also wisdom, lucidity and agility.As David Dollar and Ryan Hass of the Brookings Institution noted in a recent paper(https://www.brookings.edu/research/getting-the-china-challenge-right/), China is at once our partner, competitor and adversary.
We must not forget any of these dimensions.
The most serious problems facing humanity - pandemics, climate change, stalled economic growth - cannot be solved without China's collaboration.

And this collaboration will only be achieved by maintaining sustained diplomatic and economic relations.Moreover, given the evolution of Chinese policy under Xi Jinping, we cannot continue to fool ourselves by thinking that China's capitalist shift will lead to the gradual establishment of a Western-style democracy.
China's human rights abuses are at a level not seen since the time of Mao Zedong.

While China's Communist government may not seek to export its political or economic system abroad, it is determined to grow in prosperity and power, in its own way.It would be wrong to remain silent in the face of abuses, but it would also be ill advised to think that thunderous statements, or even economic sanctions, will make Beijing back down.
The way forward is therefore very narrow.
And it is very similar to the current policy of the Canadian government.

It remains to be seen how long Canadians, running out of patience as they are, will tolerate such a cautious policy.National PostAndrÃ© Pratte is a former senator and journalist and principal at the strategic advisory firm Navigator.

AndrÃ© Turcotte is an associate principal at Navigator.NP View: Don't turn a blind eye to China's atrocities, Mr. Trudeau - boycott the 2022 Olympics(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/np-view-dont-turn-a-blind-eye-to-chinas-atrocities-mr-trudeau-boycott-the-2022-olympics?video_autoplay=true)Terry Glavin: Two new reports shed blinding light on China's crimes.
Will the Liberals ignore them?
(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/terry-glavin-two-new-reports-shed-blinding-light-on-chinas-crimes-will-the-liberals-ignore-them) !
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Canadians are wary of China - very wary. According to our recent poll, 75 per cent of respondents described the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang province as a "genocide." Similarly, three-quarters of Canadians believe that China poses "a direct threat to Canada's national security and sovereignty." Even more troubling, 73 per cent of Canadians believe that China is "responsible" for the COVID-19 pandemic.Unusually for a country as large and diverse as Canada, this strong sense of mistrust is widespread across all regions and sociodemographic groups, with very little difference from one community to another.Clearly, in Canada as in other Western countries, the policies of Chinese President Xi Jinping's regime have profoundly undermined the goodwill that China had built up over the last several decades, as it opened its economy to the world. Last year, few people celebrated the 50th anniversary of the re-establishment of diplomatic relations between Canada and China.Today, Canada-China relations are in what is by far the most turbulent period since 1970. The detention of the "two Michaels" is obviously the most serious irritant. But there is more. Human rights abuses shock Canadians, so much so that when they were asked whether what is happening in Xinjiang is a genocide and were reminded of the dictionary definition - "the deliberate killing of a large group of people, especially those of a particular nation or ethnic group" - the vast majority said "yes."When respondents were given a choice between two statements about China's role in the pandemic - "China serves as a model for the way it managed to stop COVID-19 from spreading beyond the city of Wuhan" and "China is responsible for the global COVID-19 pandemic, because of its mismanagement of the situation in the early stages of the pandemic" - the second statement clearly won out.In this context, formulating a Canadian policy towards China is not easy. According to our survey, the vast majority (71 per cent) want Ottawa to denounce Beijing's human rights violations loudly and clearly, in concert with our allies.Yet, as former Foreign Affairs Minister FranÃ§ois-Philippe Champagne said, "While it is easy to be tough, let's continue to be smart." That is what the current situation demands: firmness on principles, certainly, but also wisdom, lucidity and agility.As David Dollar and Ryan Hass of the Brookings Institution noted in a recent paper(https://www.brookings.edu/research/getting-the-china-challenge-right/), China is at once our partner, competitor and adversary. We must not forget any of these dimensions. The most serious problems facing humanity - pandemics, climate change, stalled economic growth - cannot be solved without China's collaboration. And this collaboration will only be achieved by maintaining sustained diplomatic and economic relations.Moreover, given the evolution of Chinese policy under Xi Jinping, we cannot continue to fool ourselves by thinking that China's capitalist shift will lead to the gradual establishment of a Western-style democracy. China's human rights abuses are at a level not seen since the time of Mao Zedong. While China's Communist government may not seek to export its political or economic system abroad, it is determined to grow in prosperity and power, in its own way.It would be wrong to remain silent in the face of abuses, but it would also be ill advised to think that thunderous statements, or even economic sanctions, will make Beijing back down. The way forward is therefore very narrow. And it is very similar to the current policy of the Canadian government. It remains to be seen how long Canadians, running out of patience as they are, will tolerate such a cautious policy.National PostAndrÃ© Pratte is a former senator and journalist and principal at the strategic advisory firm Navigator.
